artifacts.replace-file-description: You are about to replace the file {name} with a new file. This will overwrite the existing file.

configurations.title: Device Configurations
configurations.limit-explain:
You can manage up to {configLimit} configurations.
For larger projects, we offer scalable plans to meet your needs at thymis.io/

hardware-devices.known-devices-without-deployment: Known devices without any current deployment
hardware-devices.no-known-hardware-devices-without-known-: No known hardware devices without known deployment

create-configuration.title: Create a new device configuration

step-1.title: Install Thymis
step-1.info: You can easily create an ISO file or a system image for your IoT device.

title.generating: We create your personal system image from Thymis.

next-steps.generating: You can do this in the meantime

finish.sd-info: Prepare a suitable data carrier for your device. USB sticks or CDs/DVDs are usually used for ISOs. For system images as .img, a data carrier such as a microSD card is recorded with the system.
finish.sd-size-warning: The data carrier must be able to hold at least 4 GB.

software-title.generated: Copy system image to data carriers

finish.software-info: The system image must be installed on the data carrier. We will give you several recommendations on how to do this.
finish.software-warning: The data carrier will be formatted when writing to it. All data will be deleted!
finish.software-permissions: You need superuser/root/administrator rights for this step.

software-windows.install: Install {balena}. After installation, you can select the image file and a disc to write to.

software-macos.step-1: 1. display your connected devices and identify the device with /dev/diskX, which stands for your desired data carrier.
software-macos.step-2: 2. remove the disc from your file system (unmount) if you have not already done so.
software-macos.step-3: 3. overwrite the data carrier with the system image using Thymis. The data carrier will be completely overwritten.

software-linux.step-1: 1. display your connected devices and identify the device with /dev/sdX, which stands for your desired data carrier.
software-linux.step-2: 2. remove the data carrier from your file system (unmount) if you have not already done so.
software-linux.step-3: 3. overwrite the data carrier with the system image using Thymis. The data carrier will be completely overwritten.

create-configuration.display-name: Display name - How the device configuration will be displayed in the UI - Required
create-configuration.display-name-tag: Display name - How the tag will be displayed in the UI
create-configuration.device-type: Device type - What type of hardware will this configuration be used on? - Required
create-configuration.tags: Device tags - What tags should be assigned to this config?
create-configuration.no-tags: Your project has no tags yet, so you can't assign any to this device configuration.
create-configuration.device-with-display-name-name-exists: Device configuration with display name "{displayName}" already exists in project.
create-configuration.tag-with-display-name-name-exists: Tag with display name "{displayName}" already exists in project.

deploy.no-changes: No changes to commit, working on a clean state
deploy.dirty-repo-tooltip: Please commit all changes before deploying
deploy.no-affected-configs-tooltip: Please select at least one config to deploy

section.installed-elsewhere: Installed on other tags or devices

config.notPassed: This definition is not passed to the device
config.passed: This definition is passed to the device
config.no-settings: No settings found for this module
config.timer-type-realtime-long: Realtime: runs at a specific date or time
config.timer-type-monotonic-long: Monotonic: runs after a time interval
config.timer-type-continuous-long: Continuous: runs as a background service
config.timer-type-continuous-description: This service will run continuously as a background daemon with automatic restart on failure. No timer configuration is needed.
config.timer-on-boot: Time after boot to start, empty to disable
config.timer-on-unit-active: Time after last start to run again, empty to disable

external-modal.title: Edit External Repository URL
external-modal.use-github-warning: For GitHub repositories, consider using the 'GitHub' type. Some features and authentication might not work.
external-modal.use-gitlab-warning: For GitLab repositories, consider using the 'GitLab' type. Some features and authentication might not work.
external-modal.file-not-absolute-warning: File paths should be absolute and start with '/'

repo-status.no-magic-string: Not a Thymis Module Repository: 'contains thymis modules' not in README.md

deleteConfirm.title: Delete {target}
deleteConfirm.text: Are you sure you want to delete {target}?

edit-hostkey.title: Edit Hostkey
edit-hostkey.scan-public-key-tooltip:
Automatically scan for the public key of the device in the network. Uses the specified target host from above.
Verify if the key is correct afterwards

secrets.name: Name
secrets.processing-description-yescrypt: This will hash the secret using the yescrypt algorithm. The hashed value will be stored in the secret. 					This should be used to set passwords for users or services that require a hashed password.
secrets.security-warning: Warning: will be available to anyone with access to installation disk

tooltip.next-occurrences: Next occurrences (times may vary by device timezone):

templates.monthly-1st-2am: First day of month at 2 AM
